text: another reader asks about girls
education and how far we've come and
what we can do to engage it you know I
think that increasingly we understand
intellectually that one of the most cost
effective tools to bring about change is
girls education and that's partly
because right now girls tend to lag in
many countries so there's a catch-up
effect partly it's because if you want
to address population issues and and and
reduce the population growth then the
best way of doing that is to educate
girls who educate a man he will on
average have fewer children but it's a
much greater effect when you educate a
girl and another reason is has to do
with what I think is the dirty little
secret of development which is that when
you educate people they earn more money
when you educate a man frankly in a lot
of the world that money that extra money
he brings in is more likely to go to
beer to partying to the brothels
whatever it may be rather than to the
family when you educate women and give
her more chance to earn money that money
is more likely to go and turn to support
her family to start a business so this
is a social intervention of enormous
power and to get all of the girls around
the world were not going to primary
school up to eighth grade to get them in
school would cost somewhere around ten
billion dollars a year which is peanuts
I mean this year in Afghanistan we're
going to spend 100 billion dollars or so
on our on our military intervention just
in terms of present cash outlays and to
think that
you know for a 10 billion for one-tenth
that we could worldwide yet virtually
all girls into school in a way that I
think would have a truly transformative
effect on society's makes me just think
that we may it'll actually know that we
should get girls in school but we
haven't taken the next step of actually
getting it done I hope that we'll do
that in the next few years
